_exec_summary.SummaryText:
BEF Foods is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's
Process Safety Management Standard (PSM): Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119;
EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions: Title 40 CFR Part 68; and EPA's Emergency
Planning and Notification: Title 40 CFR Part 355. In addition to other state and local codes
applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks
involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.
Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety.
BEF Foods is located at 640 Birch Rd., Xenia, Ohio. We manufacture some of the finest pork
products in the world. The facility includes processing tanks, piping, packaging equipment, raw
materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, an Ammonia refrigeration engine room, boilers, and miscellaneous utilities. Facility produces and ships approximately 25 million pounds of finished product each year.
The refrigeration system required for our production process necessitates the submission of this
Risk Management Plan. The refrigeration system contains 12,511 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.
BEF Foods has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.
Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and improved, as necessary.
BEF Foods has organized the information and po

lices pertaining to the process into a complete
library consisting of eight numbered volumes, some volume numbers are assigned to sets of
reference manuals, such as Operation and Maintenance manuals. This library also incorporates the use of videos and computerized tests.
Volume 1 of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates mainly policies, the following policies are included in Volume 1:
Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.
Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.
Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor.
Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been
developed to monitor and provide a "checks and balances" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.
Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, Employee training, etc..) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Risk and Reliability Manager. Volume 2 Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR ammonia Data Book).  This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components. 
Volume 3 incorporates a complete valve list, process and instrumentation diagrams, flow
schematics, and

other drawings pertinent to the production area equipment. The valve list contains information on the type, port size, identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system. Process and Instrumentation Diagrams are included for the individual system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire system. A Block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building. This volume also incorporates information on the specific system components of the production area equipment and preventative maintenance procedures.
Volume 4 incorporates a complete set of standard operating procedures for the production area
equipment. Describing the proper steps for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation, shutting down as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pumpout procedures. Also included as a part of each Standard Operating Procedure is the Technical Operating Specifications for the associate system component.
This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.
Volume 5 contains Operation and Maintenance Information for the production area equipment
including manufactures information, spare parts list, and maintenance procedures. 
Volume 6 contains the Ammonia Odor log.  It is intended to document and track ammonia odors.
Volume 7 Charging log is intended to document and track ammonia deliveries.
Volume 8 contains documents of previous RMP submittals. The purpose of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to summarize, document a

nd communicate the elements of the Risk Management Program (RMP) for the EPA.
Process Hazard Analysis Re-validation was completed in May 2019. The PHA highlighted some
deficiencies in the system. These items were addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. These items were addressed on the basis of priority (Injuries to personnel). A PSM
compliance audit was completed in September of 2023.
BEF Foods also incorporates additional safety items such as tagging of all ammonia system valves and components.
DESCRIPTION OF THE REFRIGERATION SYSTEM
BEF Foods in Xenia, Oh. is a meat-based processing and distribution facility. The facility
incorporates a standard evaporation and compression ammonia refrigeration system.
SUMMARY OF THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
BEF Foods had a release of 634 lbs. on July 15, 2023. This leak occurred on liquid transfer piping in the Engine Room above Transfer Vessel and the High Temp Pumped Recirculator HTR1. Piping was replaced. Initial observations are that the pipe failed at a pipe support. There was corrosion on the pipe, especially near the point of failure and the corrosion becomes gradually less as distance from the failure increases. The pipe support consists of a C-channel and U-bolt, and did not include a pipe saddle. There is some lateral movement possible due to the lack of pipe saddle. Initial thoughts on root cause are corrosion, possibly due to compromised insulation coupled with improper pipe support.
DESCRIPTION OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN
In the event that an ammonia leak is detected employees are to notify the onsite Maintenance
Manager and Emergency Response Facilitator. The facilitator takes an ammonia level reading using a detection device. If the facilitator determines that the ammonia level is above 25 ppm an
evacuation of the exposure area is ordered.
The Maintenance Manager determines if the leak is serious enough that outside assistance is
needed. If outside assistance is needed the local HAZMA

T organization is contacted. The
Maintenance Manager then takes appropriate procedures, such as Emergency Shutdown Standard Operating Procedures, to control the leak with personal protective devices in place.
Once the Incident Commander arrives on scene, a report is given, and the Incident Commander
takes control of the situation.
We maintain an ammonia detection system as an early warning / automatic remediation tool. Our system detects ammonia concentrations in our engine room or in the relief vent stack and
automatically initiates actions to minimize the effects of the release.
We also perform daily rounds of the ammonia refrigeration system when the facility is in production mode. This allows us to "double check" the automatic control system and assures a high level of
accuracy.
Should an event occur which would require our team members to evacuate, we are confident that our team can evacuate quickly and safely. We incorporate scheduled drills (annually) to assure that they are prepared.
BEF Foods is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of BEF Foods to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.
In the event medical services are needed, Hometown Urgent Care located at 101 S. Orange St.
45385 in Xenia, Ohio as well as Greene Memorial Hospital located at 1141 N. Monroe Dr. 45385 in
Xenia Ohio will provide medical service to our employees to include contractor employees.
WORST AND ALTERNATE CASE SCENARIOS
BEF Foods has considered a variety of scenarios that include mishandled shipping containers,
vessel or pump releases, over pressurization, and ruptured transfer hoses.
The most likely to occur at our Xenia Facility for a worst case would be a Vessel Release (Liquid)
and for an alternate release an over pressurization caused by a Rupture Disk/Safety Relief Valve to lift venting to atmosphere.
